results.title: Miracle in the loggia: Madonna with Chancellor Rolin
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Les Films d'Ici, Delta Image, FR3 and La Sept
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Jan van Eyck’s “Madonna with Chancellor Rolin” painted around 1435, is one of the first known oil paintings. Filled with microscopic detail and demonstrating early experiments with perspective, this painting features the figure of Nicolas Rolin, Chancellor of Burgundy and influential in the arts from Autin to Burgundy. As well as demonstrating the techniques and symbolism of the painting, this program also describes the historical context of The Hundred Years War.
results.title_for_label: Miracle in the loggia: Madonna with Chancellor Rolin
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alain Jaubert, Les Films d’Ici, Delta Image, FR3 and La Sept

results.title: Pictures beneath the cobblestones: July 28th, 1830 Liberty leading the people(1830)
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Les Films d'Ici, Delta Image, FR3 and La Sept
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Delacroix’s picture “Liberty leading the people” was painted in 1830 and depicts the uprising in Paris which resulted in the installation of Louis Philipe as king. This program looks in detail at the painting itself, the techniques that Delacroix used, outside influences on his art, the symbolism he uses and the reception his painting received, as well as looking briefly at the events which inspired the work.
results.title_for_label: Pictures beneath the cobblestones: July 28th, 1830 Liberty leading the people(1830)

results.title: Winter garden. Sailor's consolation. Check to song
results.creator_credit: Michael Warne, Joan Maude, John Halas, Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings”.
The second part of a series devised by Joan Maude and Michael Warre incorporating the works of writers, painters and musicians to create an experimental animated film. This part consists of three short films. ‘Winter garden’ by David Gascoigne, narrated by Michael Redgrave, painted by Barbara Jones (2:17 mins). ‘The Sailor’s consolation’ by Thomas Dibden, narrated by Stanley Holloway, drawings by John Minton (1:40 mins). ‘Check to song!’ by Owen Meredith, narrated by Eric Portman, drawings by Michael Warre (1:10 mins). Photography by W. Traylor and R. Turk, music by Matyas Seiber, edited by Jack King.

Episode number 3 of Series “Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings”.
The third part of a series devised by Joan Maude and Michael Warre incorporating the works of writers, painters and musicians to create an experimental animated film. This part consists of two short films. ‘In time of pestilence’ by Thomas Nashe, narrated by Robert Harris, drawings by Michael Ayrton (3:18 mins). ‘The Pythoness’ by Kathleen Raine, narrated by Mary Morris, drawings by Henry Moore (2:00 mins). results.title: Twa corbies. Spring and winter
results.creator_credit: Michael Warre, Joan Maude, John Halas, Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings”.
The first part of a series devised by John Maude and Michael Warre incorporating the works of writers, painters and musicians to create an experimental animated film. This part consists of two short films. ‘Twa corbies’ by anonymous narrated by John Laurie, drawings by Michael Rothenstien (2:24 mins). ‘Spring and winter’ by William Shakespeare, music by Dr. Arne and sung by Peter Pears, drawings by Mervyn Peake (5:40 mins). Photography by W. Traylor and R. Turk, music by Matyas Seiber, edited by Jack King.

results.title: Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings
results.creator_credit: Michael Warre, Joan Maude, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A four part series, containing a total of 8 short films for which contempory British painters were commissioned to script in picture, a poem. Each film is accompanied by music and narrated by English performers. The films were produced by John Halas in association with Joan Maude and Michael Warre who devised the script in co-operation with the painters.

results.title: John Gilpin
results.creator_credit: Michael Warne, Joan Maude, John Halas, Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings”.
The fourth and final part of a series devised by Joan Maude and Michael Warre incorporating the works of writers, painters and musicians to create an experimental animated film. This part consists of one short film. ‘John Gilpin’ by William Cowper, narrated by Cecil Trouncer, drawings by Ronald Searle (9:00 mins). Photography by W. Traylor and R. Turk, music by Matyas Seiber, edited by Jack King.

results.title: Master builder: Pier Luigi Nervi
results.creator_credit: Denis Postle, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Nervi is first and foremost a master craftsman, but he also has an original and revolutionary creative mind. He has an obsession for what he believes to be the supreme building material - a type of reinforced concrete. With it he has built some of the world’s most famous buildings, faster and cheaper than anyone else. The buildings for the Rome Olympics, the Pirelli building in Milan, the Unesco building in Paris, have helped build Nervi’s international reputation as a builder of tomorrow. Commentary written by Anthony Jay, spoken by Brian Redhead.

results.title: Man about Europe: Louis Armand
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Louis Armand is the most famous of all France’s civil servant/technocrats - the great moderniser with a clear and steady eye on the needs of people rather than just the capabilities of machines. During the war he organised railway resistance to the Germans, and after the war he was responsible for the electrification of the French National railway system. He persuaded the French to look for oil in the Sahara; he was the man behind Euratom; and is the leader and driving force of the French Channel Tunnel Company.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV

Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Louis Armand is the most famous of all France’s civil servant/technocrats - the great moderniser with a clear and steady eye on the needs of people rather than just the capabilities of machines. During the war he organised railway resistance to the Germans, and after the war he was responsible for the electrification of the French National railway system. He persuaded the French to look for oil in the Sahara; he was the man behind Euratom; and is the leader and driving force of the French Channel Tunnel Company.

results.title: A Man of the world: H.H. the Aga Khan
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
The Aga Khan is the creator of one of the world’s most dramatic and imaginative development schemes - a planned riviera along 35 miles of Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda. He is also the spiritual leader of more than 12 million Ismaili-Muslims scattered around the world, and a wealthy Parisian, racehourse owner, and Olympic skier. Shows the Aga Khan in a variety of activities. He comments personally, analysing himself and his different faces with the same detached lucidity he brings to all his undertakings.
